properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Dangerously cold conditions continue. What: Temperatures of minus 35 to 40; wind chills of minus 45 to 50. Where: Northwestern Ontario. When: Now through Tuesday morning, during the evening, overnight, and early morning hours. Extreme cold is forecast to last into Tuesday, at which time temperatures may moderate somewhat. Extreme cold will be possible again later this week. Actions: ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T07:55:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T15:56:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2933385403.2021

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system tracking up the American Eastern Seaboard early this week could give more than 15 centimetres of snow on Tuesday. Strong northeasterly winds will also cause blowing snow in the St Lawrence Valley. It could significantly impact rush hour traffic in urban areas. Expect hazardous driving conditions due to low visibility. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T12:36:00-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant lake effect snow possible near Georgian Bay tonight into Monday. Lake effect flurries are expected to intensify tonight for areas close to Georgian Bay. Snowfall rates of several centimetres per hour will be possible. If the lake effect bands become fairly stationary, some locations may receive in excess of 20 cm by Monday afternoon. Areas between Wasaga Beach and Owen Sound are most likely to be affected. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T12:35:19-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected. Total snow and ice pellet accumulations: 10 to 20 cm, with the potential for locally higher amounts. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h. Locations: western, central, and northeast coast of Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday afternoon into Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Snow is forecast to spread across Newfoundland Tuesday afternoon. The snow may change to or become mixed with ice pellets Tuesday night. Conditions are expected to improve Wednesday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extremely cold wind chills near minus 45 will continue this morning. Temperatures will moderate during the day today but these extremely cold wind chills will return again tonight. Temperatures will moderate Monday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T08:22:51-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls off Lake Superior have developed and will continue through tonight. What: Snow squalls. Poor visibility and total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected. When: Now through 5 a.m. Monday. Where: Areas east of Lake Superior. This includes Highway 17 between Wawa and Odena. Discussion: Lake effect snow squalls off Lake Superior will bring heavy snow and poor visibility along the eastern shore through tonight. Travel will be hazardous as a result. Remember...lake effect snow and snow squalls can cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Actions: ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T11:59:22-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Some snow Monday night followed by a possible extended period of freezing precipitation on Tuesday. Locations: Prince Edward Island. Time span: Monday evening through Tuesday evening. Remarks: An elongated, slow moving system is expected to cross the region Monday night and Tuesday. Snow ahead of this system is likely to begin Monday night then change to a prolonged period of ice pellets and/or freezing rain Tuesday morning and potentially lasting until Tuesday evening. 5 to 10 cm of snow is possible before the changeover. Note that as this system is still in early stages of development, this situation may change and it will continue to be closely monitored as it approaches in the event warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T12:04:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T20:05:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2563319461.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm likely Monday into Tuesday giving 20 to 30 cm of snow. Two rounds of precipitation are expected with this storm. The first one is expected to begin early Monday morning with 5 to 10 cm likely by afternoon. The precipitation may diminish in intensity during the afternoon, but another round of even heavier snow is expected to move in Monday evening and persist until Tuesday morning. An additional 10 to 20 cm is likely. Northeast winds gusting to 60 km/h will result in very poor visibility in blowing snow. Even higher amounts may be possible in some locations due to extra moisture coming off Lake Ontario. Locally higher amounts may also occur on the higher elevations of the escarpment. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T12:13:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T20:14:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2951205782.2021
Area: Dunnville - Caledonia - Haldimand, City of Hamilton, St. Catharines - Grimsby - Northern Niagara Region, Niagara Falls - Welland - Southern Niagara Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow Monday night and Tuesday with an extended period of freezing precipitation likely for southern New Brunswick on Tuesday. Locations: Northern and central New Brunswick for heaviest snowfall; southern half of New Brunswick for freezing precipitation. Time span: Snow beginning Monday night across all of New Brunswick and continuing through Tuesday over northern half of the province; Snow changing to ice pellets and freezing rain early Tuesday morning over southern New Brunswick then ending Tuesday evening. Remarks: An elongated, slow moving system is expected to cross the region Monday night and Tuesday. Latest indications show between 10 to 20 cm of snow could fall Monday night and Tuesday over northern New Brunswick. Over southern New Brunswick 5 to 15 cm is possible before changing to ice pellets and freezing rain Tuesday morning and potentially lasting until late afternoon or evening. Note that as this system is still in early stages of development, this situation may change and it will continue to be closely monitored as it approaches in the event warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T12:03:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T20:04:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0341022434.2021

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of precipitation is expected. Locations: southern Newfoundland and the Avalon Peninsula. Time span: Tuesday afternoon through Wednesday morning. Total snow and ice pellet accumulations: near 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h, except higher in the Wreckhouse area. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin in the southwest near noon on Tuesday then spread eastward through the afternoon. Snow will transition to ice pellets, freezing rain, or rain Tuesday night. Precipitation will taper off Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential for extended period of freezing precipitation Monday night into Tuesday. Locations: Nova Scotia. Time span: Monday night through Tuesday morning for southwestern half of the province, early Tuesday morning through late Tuesday afternoon elsewhere. Remarks: An elongated, slow moving system is expected to cross the region Monday night and Tuesday. Precipitation will start as snow over most areas Monday evening then change to a prolonged period of ice pellets and/or freezing rain Monday night into Tuesday before gradually changing to rain from southwest to northeast across the province on Tuesday. Latest indications show a potential for between 4 to 12 hours of freezing precipitation possible for some parts of the province, with the greatest risk over areas furthest inland as well as the northern half of the province on Tuesday. Note that as this system is still in early stages of development, this situation may change and it will continue to be closely monitored as it approaches in the event warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T12:02:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T20:03:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3089006324.2021

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Second winter storm has arrived. On the heels of a snow-producing storm on Saturday, a Pacific frontal system has arrived on the south coast this morning, spreading snow to the Metro Vancouver region. The snow is expected to become mixed with rain late this afternoon in some areas as another system reaches the region. As is often the case, areas inland and those in the path of the Fraser Valley outflow winds particularly can expect snow to continue through Monday. Snowfall amounts will vary due to the timing of the transition and are likely to be much higher over higher terrain as the rain-snow line is expected to fluctuate between sea level and 200 metres tonight and Monday. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T11:04:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T19:05:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1353550403.2021
Area: Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Metro Vancouver - southwest including Richmond and Delta
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of severely cold wind chills continues. An Arctic ridge of high pressure has allowed for a very cold air mass to settle over southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba. Extreme cold values of -40 to -50 have are expected to return again this evening. Some areas will combine light winds and temperatures near -35 while others will show warming with stronger winds, but all areas of southern Saskatchewan and Manitoba will be affected. As the ridge slowly pushes East, extreme wind chill values are expected to gradually moderate towards seasonal normals beginning Monday morning for Saskatchewan. Most areas of southern Manitoba will have these extreme wind chills moderate throughout the day but are expected to redevelop for Tuesday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T13:35:46-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow Monday night and Tuesday with possible extended period of freezing precipitation Tuesday afternoon and evening. Locations: Iles de la Madeleine Time span: Beginning later Monday evening through Tuesday evening. Remarks: An elongated, slow moving system is expected to cross the region Monday night and Tuesday. Snow ahead of this system is likely to begin later Monday night then change to a prolonged period of ice pellets and/or freezing rain Tuesday afternoon and continue until Tuesday evening. Snow amounts could reach or exceed 15 cm before the changeover. Note that as this system is still in early stages of development, this situation may change and it will continue to be closely monitored as it approaches in the event warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T12:05:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T20:06:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0336676777.2021
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. Arctic air will remain over the region. Expect extreme cold wind chill values of near minus 45 during the overnight and morning hours. Temperatures are forecast to gradually rise early this week. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T17:46:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-15T01:47:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3460599370.2021
Area: Watson Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values approaching minus 45 are expected to develop again tonight. Extreme cold conditions are not expected beyond tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T13:23:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T21:24:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2675949037.2021
Area: Peawanuck, Sandy Lake - Weagamow Lake - Deer Lake, Pikangikum - Poplar Hill - MacDowell, Summer Beaver - Wunnummin Lake - Kingfisher Lake, Pickle Lake - Cat Lake, Webequie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall likely Monday night into Tuesday. Light snow is expected to affect the area Monday morning and afternoon with a few centimetres possible. A much more significant area of snow will move into the region Monday evening. The snow will likely fall heavily at times and continue into Tuesday morning. Total amounts of 15 to 25 cm are possible. Snowfall warnings may be issued as this event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T12:37:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T20:38:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1372594066.2021
Area: Gatineau, Uxbridge - Beaverton - Northern Durham Region, Newmarket - Georgina - Northern York Region, Belleville - Quinte West - Eastern Northumberland County, Cobourg - Colborne - Western Northumberland County, Tamworth - Sydenham - South Frontenac, Stirling - Tweed - Madoc, Kingston - Odessa - Frontenac Islands, Napanee - Consecon, Picton - Sandbanks Park, Merrickville-Wolford - Kemptville, Westport - Charleston Lake, Brockville - Prescott, Gananoque - Mallorytown, Maxville - Alexandria, Cornwall - Lancaster, Winchester - Newington, Morrisburg - Long Sault, Kaladar - Bannockburn - Bon Echo Park, Apsley - Woodview - Northern Peterborough County, Lindsay - Southern Kawartha Lakes, Peterborough City - Lakefield - Southern Peterborough County, Prescott and Russell, Smiths Falls - Perth - Eastern Lanark County, Plevna - Sharbot Lake - Western Lanark County, Ottawa North - Kanata - Orléans, Ottawa South - Richmond - Metcalfe

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VANDERHOOF (February 14, 2021 08:00 - Prince George) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Prince George and Quesnel due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes; respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-15T11:45:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-02-14T19:46:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0307819362.2021
Area: Cariboo - north including Quesnel, Prince George
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of severely cold wind chills continues. An Arctic ridge of high pressure has allowed for a very cold air mass to settle over southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba. Extreme cold values of -40 to -50 have are expected to return again this evening. Some areas will combine light winds and temperatures near -35 while others will show warming with stronger winds, but all areas of southern Saskatchewan and Manitoba will be affected. As the ridge slowly pushes East, extreme wind chill values are expected to gradually moderate towards seasonal normals beginning Monday morning for Saskatchewan. Most areas of southern Manitoba will have these extreme wind chills moderate throughout the day but are expected to redevelop for Tuesday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T13:35:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T21:36:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3659689884.2021

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions will persist until this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A second winter storm has arrived this morning and will persist into Tuesday giving hazardous winter conditions to the Fraser Valley. Light snow has begun as a Pacific front crosses the South Coast. It will become moderate tonight and intensify on Monday as another system reaches the region. Snow accumulations are expected to reach 10 to 20 cm by Monday afternoon. Periods of freezing rain are likely to occur locally tonight through Monday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T11:13:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T19:14:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3762930008.2021
Area: Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 5 to 10 cm is expected. A Pacific front will cross Vancouver Island today spreading snow over West Vancouver Island. The snow will change to rain this afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected today. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T02:07:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T17:51:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1172079863.2021
Area: West Vancouver Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A Pacific front will cross Vancouver Island tonight spreading snow over the Malahat Highway. The snow is expected to become mixed with rain this evening. Snow mixed with rain will continue through Monday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected by Monday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T15:11:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T23:12:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0713440152.2021
Area: Malahat Highway - Goldstream to Mill Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A Pacific front will cross Vancouver Island tonight spreading snow over the Sunshine Coast and most regions of Vancouver Island. The snow will change over to rain over Greater Victoria and the Southern Gulf Islands this evening but is expected to continue as snow mixed with rain until Monday morning over the other regions. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T15:20:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T23:21:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3760972284.2021
Area: East Vancouver Island - Duncan to Nanaimo, East Vancouver Island - Nanoose Bay to Fanny Bay, East Vancouver Island - Courtenay to Campbell River, Inland Vancouver Island, Greater Victoria, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Southern Gulf Islands
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are possible tonight. Lake effect flurries off Lake Huron will continue today, but are expected to strengthen this evening. Snow squalls tonight are expected to be confined to areas close to the shoreline. Snowfall rates under the snow squalls may reach 5 to 10 cm per hour, but the snow bands should shift somewhat as the night progresses. Snowfall amounts may exceed 20 cm by Monday morning with the highest amounts expected near Lake Huron from Inverhuron to Port Albert. The activity should diminish later Monday morning. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR VANDERHOOF (February 14, 2021 08:00 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment & Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Vanderhoof due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes; respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-15T11:40:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2021-02-14T19:41:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1873498970.2021
Area: Stuart - Nechako
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A second winter storm has arrived today and will persist into Tuesday giving hazardous winter conditions to the Fraser Valley. Light snow has begun as a Pacific front crosses the South Coast. It will spread eastward to Hope tonight and intensify on Monday as another system reaches the region. Snow accumulations are expected to reach 10 to 20 cm by Monday night. An additional 5 to 10 cm is possible on Tuesday before the precipitation changes to rain but the details are uncertain at this time. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T15:47:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T23:48:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2049956675.2021
Area: Fraser Valley - east including Hope
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of severely cold wind chills continues. An Arctic ridge of high pressure has allowed for a very cold air mass to settle over southern Saskatchewan and southern Manitoba. Extreme cold values of -40 to -50 have are expected to return again this evening. Some areas will combine light winds and temperatures near -35 while others will show warming with stronger winds, but all areas of southern Saskatchewan and Manitoba will be affected. As the ridge slowly pushes East, extreme wind chill values are expected to gradually moderate towards seasonal normals beginning Monday morning for Saskatchewan. Most areas of southern Manitoba will have these extreme wind chills moderate throughout the day but are expected to redevelop for Tuesday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T13:35:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-14T21:36:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1255344135.2021
Area: Lake Winnipegosis, Lake Winnipeg - north basin, Lake Winnipeg - south basin, Lake Manitoba
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills continues. Arctic air will remain over the region. Expect extreme cold wind chill values of near minus 45 during the overnight and morning hours. Temperatures are forecast to gradually rise early this week. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Two rounds of precipitation are expected Monday into Tuesday morning across portions of southern Ontario. The first one is expected to begin overnight and persist until Monday afternoon. General amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible, though snow squall activity is possible near Lake Huron which may result in higher amounts. The precipitation may diminish during the afternoon, but another round of even heavier snow is expected to move in Monday evening and persist until Tuesday morning. An additional 10 to 15 cm is likely. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-15T12:15:06-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Two rounds of precipitation are expected Monday into Tuesday morning across portions of southern Ontario. The first one is expected to begin overnight or early Monday morning with 5 cm of snow expected by afternoon. Potentially higher amounts of up to 10 cm may occur near Lake Erie. The precipitation may diminish during the afternoon, but another round of even heavier snow is expected to move in Monday evening and persist until Tuesday morning. An additional 10 to 20 cm is likely. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
